Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Between 13 and 18 May 2014 a low-pressure cyclone designated Tamara and Yvette affected a large area of Southeastern and Central Europe, causing floods and landslides. Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina suffered the greatest damage, as the rain was the heaviest in 120 years of recorded weather measurements.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: By 20 May, at least 62 people had died as a result of the flooding, and hundreds of thousands had been forced from their homes.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The city of Obrenovac was hit hardest by the floods, with an estimated 90% of the town flooded.

At a press conference on 19 May, the Director of Police of Republika Srpska gave the names of 17 confirmed victims: 10 in Doboj, 2 in Šamac, 2 in Modriča and one each in Bijeljina, Vlasenica and Donji Žabar.
As of 20 May, there were 24 confirmed deaths in Bosnia and Herzegovina: 17 in Republika Srpska and 7 in the Federation.
As of 20 May, there were 24 confirmed deaths in Bosnia and Herzegovina: 17 in Republika Srpska and 7 in the Federation.
In Vrancea County, a 50-year-old man was carried away by the flood and found dead the next morning.
Floods and strong winds from the cyclone also reached Slovakia, where an elderly man drowned.

Time_with_Annotation: Between 13 and 18 May 2014 a low-pressure cyclone[9] designated Tamara and Yvette affected a large area of Southeastern and Central Europe, causing floods and landslides.

Total_Insured_Damage_Per_Country.Total_Insured_Damage_Assessment_with_ann: Damage in Serbia, jointly estimated by EU, World Bank group and UN officials, stands at 1,55 billion euros.
Officials in Bosnia stated that the damage could exceed that of the Bosnian War.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Insured_Da.Insured_Damage_Assessment_with_annotatio: The city of Obrenovac was hit hardest by the floods, with an estimated 90% of the town flooded.
Around 500 houses were seriously damaged and at least 20 houses are completely uninhabitable.
Part of the village of Rebelj in Valjevo municipality was annihilated by landslides.
At Mali Zvornik, a giant hill threatened to slide into the river and cut its flow, endangering that town and Zvornik across the river.
Peak flood waters from Sava river hit Šabac on 18 May, but the embankments survived, strengthened by efforts of the army and several thousands volunteers.
Further east, along the valleys of Morava and Mlava rivers, city centers of Paraćin, Petrovac na Mlavi, Svilajnac and Smederevska Palanka were flooded.

The Bosna river in central Bosnia completely flooded the cities of Doboj, Maglaj, Zavidovići and Šamac, while the Kolubara, near Belgrade, did the same to Obrenovac; those cities had the major share of victims.
The entire hamlet of Parići in Hrasno Donje, municipality of Kalesija, was swept away by landslides.
The embankment on the Sava River was breached near Rajevo Selo and Račinovci, and thus evacuation was ordered for Gunja, Rajevo Selo and Račinovci.
One of the most critical points was the embankment of the Sava river in Slavonski Šamac, where the confluence of the Bosna and Sava is located.
There were also floods in Banovina region, in the towns of Hrvatska Kostajnica and Dvor, mostly caused by the river Una, whose level had not been as high since 1955.
In Vrancea County, a 50-year-old man was carried away by the flood and found dead the next morning.

Bucharest was devastated by a storm accompanied by hail and strong winds. Several streets were flooded, trees were uprooted, and a thick layer of ice covered important transport arteries, paralyzing the traffic in the capital.

Total_Summary_Displacement.Total_Displacement_Annotation: By 20 May, at least 62 people had died as a result of the flooding, and hundreds of thousands had been forced from their homes.

Total_Displacement_Per_Country.Displacement_with_annotation: As of 20 May the total number of evacuated persons exceeded 30,000.

Most of northern Bosnia was flooded, with the Bosna river valley hitting hardest. Other affected areas included the Sarajevo Canton and Tuzla Canton. Northern and northeastern Bosnia, including the region of Semberija, was also flooded.
As of 19 May, around 15,000 people in easternmost parts of Croatia were evacuated from their homes.
Over 8,000 people were isolated and nearly 2,000 hectares of land were covered by water.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Displaceme.Displacement_with_annotation: As of 20 May the total number of evacuated persons exceeded 30,000.

The Bosna river in central Bosnia completely flooded the cities of Doboj, Maglaj, Zavidovići and Šamac, while the Kolubara, near Belgrade, did the same to Obrenovac; those cities had the major share of victims.
As of 19 May, around 15,000 people in easternmost parts of Croatia were evacuated from their homes.
Over 8,000 people were isolated and nearly 2,000 hectares of land were covered by water.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_an: Assessments of the damage range up to €3.5 billion for Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina.

Total_Economic_Damage_Per_Country.Total_Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_an: Damage in Serbia, jointly estimated by EU, World Bank group and UN officials, stands at 1,55 billion euros.
Officials in Bosnia stated that the damage could exceed that of the Bosnian War.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Economic_D.Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_annotati: The city of Obrenovac was hit hardest by the floods, with an estimated 90% of the town flooded.
Around 500 houses were seriously damaged and at least 20 houses are completely uninhabitable.
Part of the village of Rebelj in Valjevo municipality was annihilated by landslides.
Peak flood waters from Sava river hit Šabac on 18 May, but the embankments survived, strengthened by efforts of the army and several thousands volunteers.
Further east, along the valleys of Morava and Mlava rivers, city centers of Paraćin, Petrovac na Mlavi, Svilajnac and Smederevska Palanka were flooded.
The largest thermoelectric power plant in Serbia, TPP Nikola Tesla, which supplies close to 50% of electricity in Serbia, lies in the vicinity of Obrenovac, but was saved from danger.
However, flood waters filled the largest coal field of RB Kolubara with 210 million cubic meters of water, more than the volume of Vlasina lake, and its pumping out is expected to take months.

Further east, the thermoelectric power plant TPP Kostolac, which supplies 11% of electricity in Serbia, was threatened by floods from the Mlava river, but the water had not breached the innermost ring of defenses.

The Belgrade–Bar railway was severed at several locations in western Serbia, and has been closed; basic reparations took about a month to complete, and afterwards the trains were forced to take a several-hours detour.

The Bosna river in central Bosnia completely flooded the cities of Doboj, Maglaj, Zavidovići and Šamac, while the Kolubara, near Belgrade, did the same to Obrenovac; those cities had the major share of victims.
The entire hamlet of Parići in Hrasno Donje, municipality of Kalesija, was swept away by landslides.
The embankment on the Sava River was breached near Rajevo Selo and Račinovci, and thus evacuation was ordered for Gunja, Rajevo Selo and Račinovci.
One of the most critical points was the embankment of the Sava river in Slavonski Šamac, where the confluence of the Bosna and Sava is located.
There were also floods in Banovina region, in the towns of Hrvatska Kostajnica and Dvor, mostly caused by the river Una, whose level had not been as high since 1955.
In Vrancea County, a 50-year-old man was carried away by the flood and found dead the next morning.

Bucharest was devastated by a storm accompanied by hail and strong winds. Several streets were flooded, trees were uprooted, and a thick layer of ice covered important transport arteries, paralyzing the traffic in the capital.

Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Rainfall: Between 13 and 18 May 2014 a low-pressure cyclone designated Tamara and Yvette affected a large area of Southeastern and Central Europe, causing floods and landslides. Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina suffered the greatest damage, as the rain was the heaviest in 120 years of recorded weather measurements.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Flood: By 20 May, at least 62 people had died as a result of the flooding, and hundreds of thousands had been forced from their homes. Towns of Obrenovac in Serbia and Doboj in Bosnia and Herzegovina account for most victims, after being inundated by several-meter high waters from nearby rivers.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Landslide: Floodwaters caused over 2,000 landslides across Southeast Europe, spreading damage across many towns and villages.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Hail: Bucharest was devastated by a storm accompanied by hail and strong winds.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Wind: Bucharest was devastated by a storm accompanied by hail and strong winds.

Around 500 houses were seriously damaged and at least 20 houses are completely uninhabitable.
Part of the village of Rebelj in Valjevo municipality was annihilated by landslides.
Further east, along the valleys of Morava and Mlava rivers, city centers of Paraćin, Petrovac na Mlavi, Svilajnac and Smederevska Palanka were flooded.
The town of Maglaj experienced the average rainfall of two months in under 48 hours.
In the city of Zavidovići, a footbridge was filmed being swept down the Bosna river and crashing into another bridge.
The entire hamlet of Parići in Hrasno Donje, municipality of Kalesija, was swept away by landslides.
The embankment on the Sava River was breached near Rajevo Selo and Račinovci, and thus evacuation was ordered for Gunja, Rajevo Selo and Račinovci.
One of the most critical points was the embankment of the Sava river in Slavonski Šamac, where the confluence of the Bosna and Sava is located.
There were also floods in Banovina region, in the towns of Hrvatska Kostajnica and Dvor, mostly caused by the river Una, whose level had not been as high since 1955.
In Vrancea County, a 50-year-old man was carried away by the flood and found dead the next morning.

Bucharest was devastated by a storm accompanied by hail and strong winds. Several streets were flooded, trees were uprooted, and a thick layer of ice covered important transport arteries, paralyzing the traffic in the capital.
